messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Timothy Wall <twall@...> wrote:
>
> Vincent Massol wrote a plugin for maven that enabled the abbot
> library for GUI testing for web-started applications, so there might
> be something there that could be generalized (or maybe already is)
> for generic JUnit tests (abbot is a junit extension for testing UI
> components).

THanks Tim for the answer, but unluckily I think the approach there is different.

AFAIK that plugin allows for automated GUI testing by starting java web start itself in a
standard way, and just automates the GUI testing by providing a sort of 'programmed bot'
which test the GUI.

My goal is completely different. I do not want to test a JWS application in a standard JWS
environment, since that will require to have a full jnlp deployment (jnlp file, jar archives
done, etc...) each time I have to test.

I would love to test my application in a standard java environment inside my IDE for
debugging/automated junit testing.

This can be easily done for a java web start application, since it's a standard java
application after all. The problem is when you make use of specific jnlp APIs: even though
the interfaces are available in the jnlp.jar included with every JVM, the implementation
classes along with all the needed system properties and tidbits gets loaded ONLY when the
application is started from the javaws executable.

This effectively forbid you to use automated testing/debugging inside your usual IDE (I use
eclipse), and you are forced to make up a jnlp package EACH TIME you want to test, for
every single line of code you modify.

I have yet to find a way to test JNLP classes INSIDE an IDE without requiring a full
deployment, and have yet to find how can I do some automated testing with JUnit for these
classes as well.

This is my problem :)
